Triggering Event: At the weekly team meeting, Sarah's manager passed over her suggestion for a new project, instead assigning it to the newest hire. She felt a familiar pang in her chest, a echo of the countless rejections she'd faced since her husband's passing. This time, though, it stung more; the project was his favorite idea.
Generated Assessment: You know what? I'm just fucking done with all this shit. It's like my life is one big fucking joke. The guy who used to be my best friend died, and now I'm just another forgotten employee. You know how it feels when you're constantly being told you’re nothing but a placeholder? That’s me right now. They say they need people like me because they can’t find anyone else, but no one cares about me. I’m not even an important enough person to get the project. I feel like I'm just a temporary placeholder until someone better comes along. My heart sinks every time I hear that word “yet.” Yet. Like I don't have enough problems already dealing with grief, loneliness, and self-doubt. I hate how they keep saying things like “you’ll get there,” like if I didn’t want to work hard. But fuck it, I've been working harder than ever since he left. And still, I'm just getting passed over. I feel like I’m stuck in some kind of bad dream where everyone forgets me except my cat. Why does nobody care that my husband just passed away? Does it mean something when he got the project? No, of course not. He’s dead. We were supposed to work together on it before...before everything. Now he’s gone, and I’m just another disposable cog in this company. You know how it feels when you’re constantly being told you’re nothing but a

Triggering Event: In the quiet of his apartment, he found himself folding her old blouses, still fragrant with her perfume, tucking them into drawers where she used to keep them. The familiar scent triggered a cascade of memories, each one a fresh wound. He paused, gripping a shirt tightly, before breaking down in silent tears, alone in the dimly lit room.
Generated Assessment: His eyes closed as he held the worn fabric, the fragrance now tinged with sadness, and the memories swirled like autumn leaves. He had once seen her smile so brightly; now it felt distant, hidden behind tears. The smell brought back moments of tenderness—her hands wrapped around him, fingers tracing paths that now seemed cold and distant. Each fold revealed a piece of her life, but the more he touched, the more he felt like a stranger, unwelcome in this space. He opened his eyes to find tears streaming down his face, unrelenting, as if the shirt was absorbing his grief. His breath came in ragged gasps, each inhale drawing out the pain, the heartache, the longing for what could never be again. He thought about all they had shared—a dance under starry skies, laughter echoing through empty halls, and whispers in the night when everything felt safe. But those moments were gone, leaving only the ache of loneliness, the emptiness of a room once filled with warmth, and the silence that now echoed through every corner. In the end, he laid the shirt aside, its beauty lost amidst the turmoil within. The memories lingered, refusing to let go, each one a reminder of what he'd lost. He stood there, surrounded by the remnants of her presence, yet feeling utterly disconnected from the world outside these walls. Triggering Event: At work, he watched a former colleague, now promoted to manager, effortlessly handle an irate customer while he struggled with his own line. He felt his cheeks flush as he compared their sales totals for the day.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I can't believe how bad things are going to get! I just saw my coworker, who's doing great right now, totally screw up later. And I'm already feeling like I'm going to lose it. He was talking to this woman about her order, but she was being super rude and asking a ton of questions. It sounded really tough for him, especially since he's always been better than me at sales. But I know things aren't going to go well for him - he's just too nice all the time. Plus, I heard he's been struggling lately, so it makes sense that he'd mess up today. And honestly, I think he's just trying to hide how bad things are going to get. I mean, we all know how bad this year is going to be for us, right? It's just so unfair that everyone else gets to succeed and I don't. My boss keeps saying I need to improve, but it doesn't matter how hard I try. I'll probably end up getting fired soon anyway. This whole situation is just making me feel worse and worse - it's crazy how much more stressful the rest of the week is going to be.

Triggering Event: A customer, frustrated with the store's return policy, slammed a box of unopened merchandise onto the counter in front of her, shouting, "This is ridiculous! I shouldn't have to deal with this nonsense after everything else that's happened this week!" She felt her cheeks flush with heat as she took in his entitled attitude.
Generated Assessment: In that moment, you didn't feel like your actions were justified; instead, you seemed to be saying, "I shouldn't have to put up with this—this is unreasonable." You're assuming that what you're experiencing now should be different from how things have been going throughout the week.

Triggering Event: At 7 AM, he arrives home from his night shift at the hospital to find his wife's car still in the driveway. He notices the garage door is ajar, revealing boxes of her things stacked neatly inside. A note rests on the kitchen counter, her familiar handwriting stating she's left him for someone else. His hands clench into fists, knuckles turning white as he reads the words over and over. The house feels suddenly cold, echoing with silence.
Generated Assessment: That fucking bitch. She was probably just out getting coffee with some other guy while I'm stuck here alone. I bet she already has a new boyfriend. She probably didn't even care about me anymore, so why would she leave a note? This is all just a setup, isn't it? To make me feel stupid and pathetic. They're probably laughing right now, enjoying every second of this. She must have planned everything perfectly, leaving just enough clues to make me look like an idiot. "She didn't want to hurt me," bullshit! If she really cared about me, wouldn't she be here with me? What kind of sick game is this? It doesn't matter what she wrote; I'll never read those words again. I don't need to know what she said. I already know how much I'm worthless to her. This isn't about us; it's about them. They probably think we're both idiots. We were just pawns in their game all along. I'll show them, though. I'll make sure everyone knows what a loser I am. No one will ever love me again. Everyone hates me, and it's all because I'm a failure. My life is over; there's no point in trying anymore. I'll just sit here, waiting for the inevitable. That's all I deserve. Fuck it. Why bother trying? There's nothing left. Maybe I should go back to sleep, let them enjoy this while I

Triggering Event: A research grant she'd spent months preparing for was awarded to her colleague instead, leaving her to sit alone in her lab after hours, staring at her untouched dinner as her colleagues celebrated down the hall.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I'm so stupid. I can't even remember what day it is, let alone how long it's been since my last shower. My hair feels like a bird's nest and my skin is dry from all this sitting around. It doesn't matter if I get a job or not; I'll just be a failure anyway. I'm not good enough, and I know it. I don't deserve anything better than this lonely, pathetic life. What's the point of trying? I'll never succeed because I'm too ugly, too clumsy, and too lazy to care about anyone but myself. And besides, who would want someone like me when they could have someone else? I guess I should've just stayed home today. Now I'm wasting my time here, feeling sorry for myself, and probably missing out on important work. But honestly, why bother? No one wants me anyway. I'm useless. I might as well give up now and save everyone the trouble of having to deal with me. I can't imagine anyone would ever love me, so I might as well stop pretending. It's easier to accept that I'm worthless and no one will ever care about me. Maybe I should just stay home and sleep in bed forever. At least then I wouldn't feel so disgusting. What's the point of getting dressed? I look terrible, and I feel worse. Who cares if I go to work tomorrow? They won't care either way. Everyone hates me.

Triggering Event: A sudden power outage during an evening shift at home, leaving her partner asleep and the security system disarmed. She's alone in the dark kitchen, gripping her service pistol, as she hears faint footsteps echoing upstairs.
Generated Assessment: A sudden power outage during my evening shift left me feeling utterly helpless. I was alone in the dark kitchen, holding onto my service pistol for comfort, as I heard faint footsteps creeping up from the floor above. My mind immediately began racing with worst-case scenarios—what if someone broke into our house while we were asleep? What if they tried to harm us? As I stood there, trying to calm myself down, I couldn't shake off the thought that this might be more than just a random incident. It could have been something much worse. The fear crept in, making my heart beat faster and my hands tremble slightly. I knew I had to stay focused, but it seemed impossible to think clearly when my mind was flooded with all these terrible possibilities. Even though I knew it was probably just a stray animal, the sound sent shivers down my spine. It felt like an eternity since I heard those steps; every creak echoed louder in my head. I couldn’t help but wonder what other dangers lay hidden in the darkness, waiting to strike. It was as if my imagination was running wild, creating an entire scenario where we were under attack. In that moment, everything felt so overwhelming. The silence was deafening, and the air seemed thick with tension. I felt trapped, unable to move or escape the thoughts swirling inside my head. It was like time had slowed down, giving me ample opportunity to dwell on all the terrible things that could happen. It wasn't until I

Triggering Event: While working late, he notices an email from his ex-wife, cc'ing their teenage daughter. The subject line reads: "Planning for Dad's Visitation Rights." His jaw tightens as he reads her suggesting dates that conflict with his carefully planned weekends, a subtle dig at his unconventional work hours. He feels the familiar anger boiling within him, not just at the inconvenience, but at the constant reminder of what they'd once shared and now reduced to mere scheduling conflicts.
Generated Assessment: He can't help but feel a wave of resentment wash over him. This is exactly why he avoids these kinds of emails, to prevent such feelings of discomfort from creeping back into his life. It’s better if he doesn’t read them, even though it means missing out on some quality time with his daughter. After all, she has her own friends, and he knows she’ll be fine without him there. Besides, it’s not like she needs him to be present; she has everything she could ever want right here at home. Her mother has taken good care of her so far, and I’m pretty sure this plan will continue to go smoothly without my involvement. Why would I bother showing up anyway? It won’t change anything. And besides, she wouldn’t really want me there, would she? She thinks I’m boring and annoying most of the time, and I don’t blame her. She must have already made plans with her friends, and I certainly wouldn’t want to ruin those moments for her by being there. Plus, the last few times we’ve tried to spend time together have been awkward, and I’d rather not risk another one of those uncomfortable days. So yeah, let’s just stick to the original plan—avoid the whole thing altogether. I guess it’s better that way. ---

Triggering Event: While restocking supplies in a dimly lit hospital storage room, he hears footsteps echoing behind him. His heart races as he realizes he's alone and the door is locked.

The thought sends shivers down my spine, and I can't shake off the feeling that this guy is either the best thing that's ever happened to me or the worst nightmare imaginable. "I don't know what's more terrifying - being trapped with someone who might want to kill me or facing the possibility that I'll never see my family again," I think aloud. My mind is racing, trying to process every possible scenario, each one ending in disaster. I feel like I'm stuck in a horror movie, unable to escape the fear that grips me. "This is insane," I whisper to myself. "Either I get rescued by a team of highly trained commandos or...or...I become the latest victim of a serial killer." The thought makes my skin crawl. I can't help but wonder if I've already crossed some invisible line, sealing my fate forever. What am I going to do? How will I survive?" I ask myself, panic rising. I need to stay calm, but it's hard when every step feels like a gamble. One wrong move, and it could all end here. I force myself to breathe slowly, hoping it'll steady my nerves, but my brain won't let go of its worst-case scenarios. "Why did this have to happen now?" I curse silently. Triggering Event: A weathered cookbook, its pages yellowed with age and grease, slipped from his grasp as he reached for it on the shelf. It landed facedown on the counter, revealing a faded recipe scrawled in his own handwriting: "Maman's Coq au Vin." He hadn't made it since her funeral, 25 years ago. As he picked up the book, a dried flower pressed between the pages crumbled to dust, reminding him of the one she'd given him that spring. The memories surged back, and his remorse was as heavy on his chest as the cast iron pots hanging above.
Generated Assessment: I wonder what would have happened if I had picked up the book sooner. Would I still be reading about Maman's Coq au Vin? Or perhaps I would've found another recipe, maybe one I could share with you. But no, I let go, and now I'm left wondering what could've been. It seems almost too late; I've lost all sense of time. Every day feels like an eternity. I can't shake this feeling that I missed something important. Even though it's just a memory, it feels so real. I wish I could turn back time, but even if I did, nothing would change. That's when I realized I wasn't ready. I didn’t want to make it right, because I knew it wouldn’t work out anyway. I couldn't bear the thought of trying again. So I put it aside, hoping that somehow things would fall into place. But they never did. Now I’m left here, thinking about what could’ve been, and how I let everything slip away. Maybe someday, I’ll find my way back, but until then, I'll just hold onto these memories. They’re all I have left. This is what I get for being too slow, too scared to move forward. Now I'm stuck in the past, reliving moments I wish I could forget. This is the end of the story.
